identity.short_description: An exquisitely restored baroque chateau at the foot of Mont Ventoux, set amidst 5 hectares of private park and forest in Provence. Built in 1725, the chateau offers 7 air-conditioned bedrooms sleeping 12-14 guests, with indoor and outdoor celebration spaces for up to 200 guests.

location.distance_to_coast: Under 1 hour to sandy Mediterranean beaches
nearby_attractions: Menerbes - setting of 'A Year in Provence'
location.landscape_description: At the foot of Mont Ventoux, at the edge of the medieval market town of Mazan, with rolling vineyards surrounding the property

historical_families: Count Francois Marie-Joseph de Paule de Sobirats and Emilienne de Damas du Rousset
history.historical_narrative: Built between 1725 and 1744 by Francois II Bernard de Saint-Andeol and his wife Marie Roman. The Romans were wealthy landowners who also launched the famous 'Carri' of Mazan, a folkloric event continuing in a 10-yearly cycle. In 1808, Count Francois Marie-Joseph de Paule de Sobirats and his wife Emilienne de Damas du Rousset became proprietors. They built the intimate chapel dedicated to Saint Andiol, consecrated by the Archbishop of Avignon on May 3, 1836. Count Francois died childless in 1859 and left the house to his great-nephew Gustave de Ripert-Barret. In 1929, the three daughters sold the property in a deplorable state. During WWII, the chateau became a home for deaf-mute and blind girls, subsequently sold to Mr. Rollin-Pinin and then the Westphal family. In 2025 — 300 years after construction began — Ellen and Tobias Alpsten acquired the Chateau du Jonquier and 4.5 ha of surrounding land.
notable_architectural_features: Coat of arms on castle facade: unicorn and lion with motto 'Robur (Strength): Make way, make way for Madame'
Classic South of France tomettes floors
Big open fireplace in Salle de Reception
Indigo and star-spangled arch above chapel altar
history.renovation_history: Careful and extensive renovations after 2025 acquisition by Ellen and Tobias Alpsten, transforming it into a 550 sq.m property with 5-star contemporary comfort. Ancient oil heating shut down and replaced with 100% green electricity.
literary_cultural_associations: Ellen Alpsten, bestselling author of the 'TSARINA' series published in 23 languages

spaces.name: Chapelle de St. Andiol
notable_features: indigo and star-spangled arch above altar
spaces.description: The chateau's own chapel consecrated by the Archbishop of Avignon in 1837, devoted to the local Provencal St. Andiol. Ideal for an intimate wedding.

spaces.name: Courtyard
spaces.description: An enclosed courtyard of 100m2 with a nod to the agricultural heritage of the chateau. Allows for al fresco dinner under the Provence skies.

spaces.name: The Southern Terrace
spaces.description: Elegant and opulent 600m2 terrace providing endless possibilities — from bucolic brunches through to divine dinners. Seats up to 200 people.

spaces.name: The Vintage Greenhouse
spaces.description: Located in the revived 'potager' of the chateau, the vintage Greenhouse creates a bucolic and authentic ambience, perfect for informal get-togethers. Available from 2027.

spaces.name: Salle de Reception
spaces.description: 180m2 indoor space that triples as a stylish hide-away from bad weather, an outdoor/indoor cocktail and reception space, and a club for dancing. No curfew applies indoors.

spaces.name: The Southern Lawn
notable_features: groups of fruit trees — quince, pomegranate, cherries and apples
view of vitality pool and chateau
spaces.description: A vast lawn with groups of fruit trees, a dream-like location for a ceremony with larger seating needs. Exchange vows with the 12x6m vitality pool and the chateau as a backdrop.

spaces.name: Wedding Island / Petanque Piste
notable_features: romantic wedding pavilion on Love Island
spaces.description: A wedding island walkway via the petanque piste area, with a romantic wedding pavilion on Love Island.

buildings.name: Le Chateau
buildings.description: An elegant and meticulously restored 550 sq.m property featuring 5-star contemporary comfort. Each room features classic South of France tomettes floors and an elegant mix of modern design, vintage Provencal pieces, and luxurious fabrics from Pierre Frey, Zoffany, and Lelievre. Every bathroom is fully modernised.

nearby_accommodation: Charming B&Bs in medieval market town of Mazan

pricing.starting_price_description: Midweek wedding April-October to privatise the entire property for 2 nights and 3 days with accommodation for 12-14 guests
price_includes: Exclusive use / privatisation of entire property

catering.brunch_description: Leisurely brunch by the pool bar on Sunday morning

drinks.bar_service_description: No corkage fees, giving complete freedom to curate your celebration. Recommended wines from local AOC Ventoux suppliers.

ceremony.chapel_details: Chapelle de St. Andiol, consecrated by the Archbishop of Avignon in 1837, seating 30 guests. Features Victorian pews, Provencal 'canne' chairing, candy-coloured silk cushions, Persian rugs, heavy cast iron candle holders, and indigo star-spangled arch above altar.
ceremony.nearby_church: Beautiful, large church in the medieval market town of Mazan; France's oldest and most famous Synagogue in nearby Carpentras available for Jewish ceremonies

amenities.pool_details: 12 x 6m vitality pool with water from natural spring, with pool bar
amenities.gardens_description: 5 hectares of walled English garden, historic enclosed park and forest. Enchanted forest dominated by ancient oaks, cypresses and giant plane trees, bordering the river Auzon. Natural spring that feeds a stream and two ponds (one with its own island). Groups of fruit trees: quince, pomegranate, cherries, apples. Hedges of cypress and oleander.

nearby_activities: Visiting Gordes, Roussillon, Menerbes hilltop villages
Swimming at La Gorges des Toulouranc

policies.noise_restrictions: Curfew at 1am outdoors; no curfew in Salle de Reception indoors

wedding_day_details.typical_weekend_flow: Friday evening: Welcome guests with a relaxed rehearsal dinner in the vintage greenhouse. Saturday: Exchange vows in the chapel, on the shaded terrace, or on the lush southern lawn. Cocktails in the flower-filled gardens or on lavender-scented terraces. Dine al fresco beneath the plane trees on the 600m2 Southern Terrace, or host a courtyard banquet under twinkling fairy lights. End the evening in the Salle de Reception, dancing the night away. Sunday morning: Leisurely brunch by the pool bar.
